title: Does Russia have any historical claim to eastern parts of Ukraine? - Quora

response.answer_text: "Historic claim" is a rather ridiculous concept. If you dig deep enough, Crimea should be split between Greece and Italy.  Modern troops of Catherine the Great kicked Ukrainian Cossacks out of the barely populated steppes. They remained barely populated until Welshman Hughes started to relocate Russian peasants there to mine coal - and founded the town then called "Hughesovka", later "Stalino", and from early 60s - Donetsk. Someone wanted to restore British Empire - perhaps you should start with Donetsk*.  What is happening in Donetsk has nothing to do with Russia and everything to do with Ukraine. People feel been abused by consecutive Ukrainian Governments. Then they elected "their" Yanukovich - and he got removed by the "Westerners". Of course Yanukovich was not "theirs" but a self-serving thug, but hey, if you can remove legally elected power by throwing rocks and burning tires, shouldn't' they try that way of getting better life? My [Jewish] great-grandfather was mining coal there - he didn't live long. It was - and in Ukraine it still is - a very hard job rich in dangers and health hazards, yet poor in pay. As I understand none of the "pro-Western" leaders did anything to get the lives of people in Donetsk closer to Western standards, and the new one appointed the people whom they blame for their misery as their Governors. Why is it so surprising that they want out - or at least to pretend they want out to get something? Sure, Russia wants them to secede - they may also want Alaska to secede from US and join Russia, however Putin's rule doesn't look that desirable across Bering Strait. What should be done to a country to want Putin - try to imagine.  Talk to them about collective bargaining, industrial relations tribunals, minimum wage, conflict of interests and NHS, and they forget Putin and pledge their loyalty to the Crown in a fortnight. At least 96% of them. (*) of course I do know that shady business dealings of one expat don't create any historic claim or historic responsibility - I used reductio ad absurdum to explain how ridiculous is the way the problem is discussed.

Yes. “Historical claim” is an ideological concept that any nation uses the way it sees fit. This is how it works in Russia. Matter of the State In the Russian political tradition, “historical claims” are defined by our mighty State. These claims wildly vacillate between the iconoclastic Communist “right of all peoples to self-determination” through the liberal notion of impoverished rule of Boris Yeltsin, “everyone take as much sovereignty as you manage to digest” to the radical nationalists on the government’s pay who claim as ours everything where the spirit of Russia’s glorious plains and Orthodox righteousness finds its home. Right now, our “historical claims” are defined by Putinist agenda for revisionist “New Yalta” deal. Boiled down, it means we’re comfortable within our current borders, but insist on a decisive say in matters right outside our perimeter. Simple rules Once this is clarified, it’s worth keeping in mind that there’s a range of what we can call “dormant historical claims”. Our Eurasianists and other radicals keep them in a state of lucid hibernation in the hope that someday the Kremlin sees their usefulness. These are kaleidoscopic and fluid in their scope. Generally, they are consistent with a few important rules rooted in our imperial past. Russia has a natural claim to every inch of the land it occupies now, even if it is populated by a non-Russian ethnicity. Attempts to separate these from Russia are considered extremism and a wicked attempt to sow discord on an ethnic basis. (This also forms the basis of our objections to the independence of Kosovo: we consider that Serbs have a historical claim to it, no matter what the local Albanians say.)Territories once ruled by our Czars, Emperors, and General Secretaries can be claimed back as an integral part of Russia.Our former territories that have a considerable number of “Russian-speaking individuals” have a natural right to vote for separation from their current country—and if they want to, become part of Russia.The territories that we were first to colonize, can be claimed back on the basis of “first arrivals”. This applies for example to Alaska and the Spitsbergen archipelago. (In our books, the First Americans have no priority to claim Alaska before us.)In the territories where our men died in wars officially designated as “liberation wars”, e.g. in WW2, we have a historical claim to influence their interpretation of history, erection or destruction of monuments and buildings, as well as their national narrative and foreign politics. Our embassies and top clergy are very vociferous in this in countries like Poland, Bulgaria, the Baltics, and Ukraine.Our historical claim to have a major say in matters concerning the countries around our perimeter, especially in former Soviet republics, is non-negotiable. If our neighbors conclude treaties and become friends with external powers who we consider threatening, these neighbors must pay a price for that.In dealings with major powers like the US, we have a historical claim to reciprocity. We don’t surround America with military bases, like they do with us, because of limited resources and love of peace. But we claim the right to make up for it by other “non-symmetrical” measures—or reciprocate it sometime in the future when new technical possibilities may arrive. In the photo below, a piece of patriotic merchandise from Russia. The print on the girl’s sweatshirt shows a good-humored Russian bear in body armor with a Kalashnikov. The rhymed text says: “Russian Mísha is the whole world’s krýsha”. Misha is an affectionate name for friendly bears in our folk tales. Krýsha (literally “roof”) is “protective muscle” required for conducting business in Russia; the best of kríshas are FSB generals, top state attorneys, and the Presidential Administration. Establishing our natural claim to give protection to anyone who needs it has made Russia the largest country in the world. We don’t see any rational reason beyond rabid Russophobia for why someone can possibly object to that.

Once and for all, Russia did not invade Ukraine or Crimea. Under a decades long treaty (Partitioning Treaty) with the Ukraine, Russia has had the right to maintain military bases in that region with maximum troop levels of about 20,000. Russian troops have been there for decades. Claim or not, the Crimean people voted overwhelmingly to seek annexation by Russia. The turnout for the vote was almost double the turnout of any American presidential election and was passed by over a 90% majority, as reported by Reuters. The Crimean people flocked to the streets to celebrate and tweeted their joy at being Russia too. Small wonder as the majority of the population of Eastern Ukraine identify themselves as "Russian" and speak Russian every day.  The USA and the EU, and their puppets, the U.N. and NATO, claim that the election was illegal, but to date, I have seen absolutely no argument backed by legal precedent backing up their claims that it was illegal. In contrast, Mubarak of Egypt used to be "elected" by 96% of the vote every damn election and no one batted an eye in the West because he was the USA's boy at the time. Whatever the case, the Russians can ignore all of the saber-rattling and posturing by the West because not only do they know that they hold all the cards-- -popular sentiment in Crimea and the majority of population are native Russian speakers-hand posed over "off-switch" for the gas line to Europe-threat of economic blackmail has only encouraged their move toward a gold backed ruble which would be pretty damn attractive in this world of toilet-paper dollars-nary a peep against Russia from other members of the BRICS coalition which is steadily moving toward introducing a new international currency to rival the petro-dollar-zero capability for a NATO or American invasion, etc. ...they also have recognized that the posturing and sabre-rattling is being done by pencil-necked bureaucrats and bankers with no concept of what they are doing. Putin has also recognized that the instigation of this drama in the Ukraine is merely a ploy to loot that country to try and prop up the flailing E.U. a little bit longer, and also to give the USA more NATO bases and locations for antagonizing Russia with treaty breaking missile bases. My prediction:  The West will let their protests dwindle away as the current governing body in the Ukraine (some might say illegal government), led by those that the US has supported all along, becomes more and more autocratic and radical because that is pretty much par for the course for USA client states, or states in which the USA has engineered "regime change".  Russia will just go about its business like an elephant pestered by mosquitoes that can never hope to pierce its thick skin.  The Crimeans will enjoy a better standard of living because they will have their pensions and welfare paid for in rubles while the Ukrainians watch their pensions and savings disappear as they join Greece, Portugal, and Spain in languishing under the economic austerity programs associated with the IMF loan repayment agreement that the current Ukrainian government is rushing to get approved.

I have seen some brash claims to the Donetsk region in Russian news recently, but this has not been discussed by Russian legislators for many years (Crimea was discussed continually for long time). So, I don't think this has much merit. IMHO, Russia would get involved militarily only in case of mass disorder, but the number of people protesting in Donetsk and Mariupol is around 200. Russia is now concerned that NATO is moving chess pieces toward Russia on a permanent basis (in Poland, Romania, Baltic states) and about NATO military exercises with Ukraine planned from June on.  Ukrainian news published an opinion poll showing that even in the Southeast, the support for "federalization" in Ukraine (which Russia pushes) is <50. Again, this is different from Crimea which has always been "autonomous" within Ukraine. The support for "federalization" in Ukraine overall is low, so Russia cannot push this for long time in good faith. Here is an old map of Ukraine which includes Southern Russia. In reality, this is not a serious claim (thanks to Joseph Boyle for finding the image).

Ukrainian patriots declare modern Ukraine as a successor state of State of Zaporozhe Cossacks Zaporozhian Cossacks - Wikipedia This state controlled only a central part of the territory of the modern Ukraine. Easter part of Ukraine, so called Slobozhanshina, Sloboda Ukraine - Wikipedia Sloboda Ukraine is a historical region, now located in Northeastern Ukraine and Southwestern Russia. It developed and flourished in the 17th and 18th centuries on the southwestern frontier of the Tsardom of Russia. In 1765 it was converted into the Sloboda Ukraine Governorate. was a part of Tzardom of Russia, colonized by “citizens” of Tzardom of Russia and by Cossacks who had been invited by Russian Tzars. Settlers were given land and money for exchange of border guard service. It happened even before Pereyaslavskaya Rada treaty. These region had been merged with Ukraine (Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic) in the early years of USSR.

Of course, yes. All cities there were founded by Russians and even now these lands are populated preliminary by ethnical Russians (well, it is a moot statement because the difference between ethnical Russians and ethnical Ukrainians speaking Russian is very subtle if exists at all. So it depends on how to count and what is the purpose of those who count.) Another question is, what is “historical claim” at all, should it be taken into consideration or not? If a city was founded in 17th century by Russians (subjects of Russian csar) does it mean that this city must always belong to Russia whatever?

One sentence: They are neighbors. As any historical neighbors anywhere in the world they have claims to each other's territory. Russians could attempt to claim the whole east of Ukraine based on the fact that once it was a part of Russian Empire, while Ukrainians could go much further and counter with Kievian Rus, to the legacy of which they have much stronger claim. Anyway such historical claims are (shall be) irrelevant in the modern world and using such a claim as a pretext to annex a part of another country is a pure form of a medieval barbarianism.

Russia's historical claim is pretty weak (not that that ever stopped an empire builder), but the trump card they hold is that like many former Russian colonies, Ukraine is home to a large ex-pat ethnic Russian population; in parts of Eastern Ukraine, this reaches 50%+, although if you take it across the board, it's lower. So Russia has an ethnicity claim, rather than a historical one.

If by "historical claim" you mean parts of Ukraine were once parts of Russia, then yes, I suppose so.With a caveat that at least in Europe, making "historical claims" is pointless and absurd. Borders here tend to change several times in a century. It's the present that matters.

Not Russia, but people of Ukraine claim to become part of Russia. Ukraine is a failed state with an antipopular Western-backed regime and puppet government. No wonder that such state is falling into pieces nowadays.

No, at the moment of USSR was being destroyed, Russia hat accepted the borders and even hat guaranteed that it will defend Ukraine in a case anyone will try to change the borders. And then betrayed making the Anschluss of parts of Ukraine on the east in Crimea.
Russia's claim to Ukraine is the same as Mexico's claim to California.  Both were historical owners of those territories.

Of course NO! If you continue the thought, Aliaska and Poland should belong to Russia, because they are “historical part” of Russian empire. USA and Australia should belong to the UK. Brazil and Cuba should belong to Spain. I guess its very stupid and dangerous as it may lead to wars.

It was never very definite what Ukraine was, with different parts being ruled by different empires.  Ukrainian nationalists are insisting on their right to the entire territory inherited from the Soviet Union, while being blindly hostile to other aspects of their Soviet heritage and Russian influence.
You should change question to: Does Ukraine have any historical claim to Russia?
Based on this map, no claim could be laid. Ukraine and Belarus clearly belonged to Poland and Lithuania. Russia must stop its activities there and turn back to its Eurasian roots.

The modern history of Crimea begins with the annexation by the Russian Empire in 1783. In 1921 the Crimean Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic was created. This republic was dissolved in 1945, and the Crimea became a province first of the Russian SSR (1945-1954) and then the Ukrainian SSR (1954-1991). Since 1991 it has had the status of an Autonomous Republic within Ukraine until its annexation by the Russian Federation in the 2014 Crimean Crisis.  History of Crimea
From the historical perspective, Russian claim on those territories is 1000 times more justifiable than the Ukrainian one.
